articles.headline: U.S. Officials Scrambled Behind the Scenes to Shield NATO Deal From Trump
articles.snippet: John R. Bolton, the national security adviser, pushed NATO ambassadors to finish a critical policy document before the alliance’s summit meeting last month so the president could not reject it.
articles.abstract: John R. Bolton, the national security adviser, pushed NATO ambassadors to finish a critical policy document before the alliance’s summit meeting last month so the president could not reject it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior American national security officials, seeking to prevent President Trump from upending a formal policy agreement at last month’s NATO meeting, pushed the military alliance’s ambassadors to complete it before the forum even began.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: As Chinese Investors Panic Over Dubious Products, Authorities Quash Protests
articles.snippet: Chinese investors poured billions into online lending platforms. Now some can’t get their money back.
articles.abstract: Chinese investors poured billions into online lending platforms. Now some can’t get their money back.
articles.lead_paragraph: In online chat groups, thousands of small investors who had put their savings into dubious digital products plotted a big protest in Beijing this week.
articles.byline: By Cao Li, Alexandra Stevenson and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: How a Blacklisted Russian Firm Won (and Lost) a Break From Trump’s Tariffs
articles.snippet: A Russian aluminum giant got a break that had eluded most others. Then it unraveled after Commerce officials realized it had been granted in error.
articles.abstract: A Russian aluminum giant got a break that had eluded most others. Then it unraveled after Commerce officials realized it had been granted in error.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of companies have asked the Trump administration for a special break from its sweeping aluminum tariffs. Few have succeeded. One that managed to get an exemption is a Russian firm currently subject to Treasury Department sanctions.

articles.headline: Facebook Banned Infowars. Now What?
articles.snippet: Slippery-slope fears about mass censorship by social media platforms are probably overblown. But many valid questions remain.
articles.abstract: Slippery-slope fears about mass censorship by social media platforms are probably overblown. But many valid questions remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Late on Sunday, after returning to his hotel room on a trip away from home, Mark Zuckerberg made a decision he had hoped to avoid.

articles.headline: An Economic Upturn Begun Under Obama Is Now Trump’s to Tout
articles.snippet: Both presidents have had trouble turning better times into higher approval ratings. But this time the challenge is in the hands of a salesman.
articles.abstract: Both presidents have had trouble turning better times into higher approval ratings. But this time the challenge is in the hands of a salesman.
articles.lead_paragraph: By nearly every standard measure, the American economy is doing well — and better than it was a year and a half ago, before Donald J. Trump was elected president. If only the debate over who deserves most of the credit were as easily judged.

articles.headline: Tensions Between Turkey and U.S. Soar as Trump Orders New Sanctions
articles.snippet: Frustrated by Turkish delays in releasing an American pastor, President Trump announced economic sanctions as Turkey’s currency plummets.
articles.abstract: Frustrated by Turkish delays in releasing an American pastor, President Trump announced economic sanctions as Turkey’s currency plummets.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A worsening dispute between the United States and Turkey reverberated through the global economy on Friday, hastening a broad flight of money from emerging markets and sowing instability throughout the Middle East as relations between the NATO allies neared a breaking point.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: At Carrier, the Factory Trump Saved, Morale Is Through the Floor
articles.snippet: Twenty months after the president-elect reached a deal to keep blue-collar jobs from leaving the country, absenteeism plagues the Indiana plant.
articles.abstract: Twenty months after the president-elect reached a deal to keep blue-collar jobs from leaving the country, absenteeism plagues the Indiana plant.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time the sun comes up, Nicole Hargrove knows if it’ll be a struggle to meet her quota at the Carrier furnace factory in Indianapolis. Six days a week, she’s on the assembly line by 6 a.m., when a buzzer sounds and starts a shift that is supposed to conclude with 1,100 newly built units. But lately, the line sometimes grinds to a premature halt, as supervisors wait for employees to straggle in — or give up and pull people off forklifts to fill in for no-shows. At the end of shifts like that, Ms. Hargrove and the others who bothered to come in have only 800 furnaces to show for their efforts.

articles.headline: Republican Governors in Blue States Find a Way to Get Along
articles.snippet: Using bipartisanship and avoiding liberal tendencies, conservative governors in states like Maryland and Massachusetts may survive a blue wave in the midterms.
articles.abstract: Using bipartisanship and avoiding liberal tendencies, conservative governors in states like Maryland and Massachusetts may survive a blue wave in the midterms.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAGERSTOWN, Md. — To keep the base happy, a group of governors has defended the federal health care law, signed new gun control legislation and stood up to President Trump when his words or policies aggrieved them. All are Republican.
